nodes.content: Help me understand the metacognitive flow framework

nodes.title: Thought
nodes.content: Let me break down the metacognitive framework systematically. It combines cognitive nodes with mental models to create structured reasoning pathways.

nodes.title: Emotion
nodes.content: There's excitement in exploring this framework - it feels like unlocking a new way of thinking. The structure provides clarity while maintaining flexibility.

nodes.title: Imagination
nodes.content: Imagine applying this to complex problems - visualizing the thought process as a tree of possibilities, each branch representing a different cognitive pathway.

nodes.title: Belief
nodes.content: I believe that making thinking visible through structured frameworks helps us become better problem solvers and decision makers.

nodes.title: Action
nodes.content: Start by selecting a real problem, choose 5 mental models, generate 5 cognitive flows per model, score them, and execute the best approach.
The metacognitive flow framework is a structured reasoning approach that combines 5 cognitive nodes (Thought, Emotion, Imagination, Belief, Action) with mental models to solve complex problems.

nodes.title: Example
nodes.content: Let's say you're deciding whether to refactor a legacy codebase. Using First Principles Thinking with a Thought→Imagination→Analysis flow helps break down assumptions.

nodes.title: Analysis
nodes.content: The framework excels when you need systematic thinking. It prevents cognitive bias by forcing you to consider multiple perspectives through different node types.
Here's a practical example: When deciding on architecture for a new feature, use System Thinking + Thought→Imagination→Belief flow to map dependencies and envision solutions.
